Award.AwardTitle: Chip-scale ultrashort pulsed lasers for two-photon fluorescence imaging and sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0967257
Schnitzer

The applicants plan to create mode-locked, ultrashort-pulsed lasers that are made in a monolithic manner on a single semiconductor wafer using photonic crystal technology. In the long run, the resulting lasers could reshape how life scientists, educators and students use nonlinear optical microscopy. For researchers, large-scale or distributed two-photon imaging systems could provide wholly new capabilities for inspecting the biological world or screening large libraries of specimens by the combined use of many microscopes in parallel. The lasers will also find immediate usage in their own neuroscience research, for visualizing neuronal dynamics in awake behaving mice. In combination with microfabricated scanning mirrors, the chip-scale lasers will allow us to make tiny two-photon microscopes such that each mouse carries its own microscope on its cranium The research will be a collaboration between two Stanford labs of complementary expertise. James Harris is a pioneer in the use of molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) techniques for growing semiconductor optical devices. Mark Schnitzer is deeply experienced in the design and construction of two-photon microscopes and their usages for brain imaging. As a proof-of-principle demonstration, the two groups will design, build, test, and refine 10 tiny two-photon microscopes based on chip-scale lasers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report: Towards a Monolithic Slow Light Optical Waveguide Passively Mode Locked Laser for Two Photon Microscopy

We made significant progress towards our goal to create a special type of laser for a novel type of portable microscope. This type of laser is called a passively mode locked slow light optical waveguide laser, and it will be very useful for two-photon microscopy, which is widely used in biological research. We proposed a novel slow light photonic crystal waveguide design that has a factor of 50 lower spectral dispersion than previous designs and has an especially broad spectral (color of the light) spread. These novel features of the laser will open up new opportunities for creating active photonic crystal devices, including mode-locked lasers and slow light optical amplifiers.

We have also demonstrated a novel high gain 920nm AlInGaAs quantum dot mode-locked laser that will enable a new range of applications for ultrashort pulsed semiconductor lasers at room temperature, including two-photon microscopy. If successful, our combined slow light master oscillator power amplifier quantum dot lasers will make two-photon microscopy much more economical, enabling larger scale and broader impact experiments within the biological imaging community.  We expect this could have broad impact on biological research.

We began the project with design and fabrication of a simpler semiconductor mode locked laser. Through simulation work we determined that a significant slow light effect can be incorporated into a mode-locked laser cavity with sufficient gain and bandwidth to produce sub-picosecond pulses. The slow light waveguide can also be designed to be dispersion compensated and provide pulse compression, enabling ultrashort, high-energy laser pulses capable of powering two photon microscopy. We also demonstrated a process for fabricating photonic crystal mode-locked lasers, which produced devices that work in continuous mode operation.

In summary, we made significant progress in the development of a monolithic (single chip) slow light optical waveguide passively mode-locked laser. We presented the preliminary results for the first 920 nm mode-locked laser using novel high gain AlInGaAs quantum dots grown by molecular beam epitaxy. These devices are currently being characterized, and then fabrication of slow-light photonic crystal mode-locked lasers will begin, hopefully achieving mode-locking. A novel method of electrically injecting photonic crystal lasers is also being pursued, and these technologies will be merged to make fully integrated mode locked lasers for two photon microscopy.
